children.text:
Content Standard 1: Skills and Techniques
Students shall demonstrate and apply the essential skills and techniques to produce music.
Sing

Sing a variety of simple songs alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • fast and slow
  • high and low pitch
  • loud and soft

Sing a variety of simple songs alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • quarter notes, quarter rests, and paired eighth notes
  • fast and slow
  • melodic patterns (e.g., sol-mi/5-3, sol-mi-la/5-3-6)
  • dynamic levels- forte (f) and piano (p)
  • duple and triple meter
  • cumulative songs

Sing a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • half notes and half rests
  • fast and slow
  • more complex melodic patterns (sol-mi-la-do/5-3-6-1, steps, skips, repeating tones)
  • dynamic levels-forte (f) and piano (p)
  • duple and triple meter
  • call and response

Sing a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • dotted half notes
  • variety of tempi (e.g., allegro, adagio)
  • more complex melodic patterns (e.g., pentatonic and major scales, steps, skips, leaps, repeating tones)
  • change in dynamic levels-crescendo and decrescendo
  • duple and triple meter
  • rounds

Sing a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • whole notes, whole rests, four sixteenth notes, and triplets
  • variety of tempi changes (e.g., accelerando, ritardando)
  • more complex melodic patterns (e.g., pentatonic, major, and minor scales)
  • variety of dynamic levels [e.g., pianissimo (pp), mezzo piano (mp), mezzo forte (mf), fortissimo (ff)]
  • duple and triple meter
  • partner songs

Sing a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • eighth note and sixteenth note patterns
  • variety of tempi (e.g., andante, moderato)
  • major tonalities
  • dynamic levels- pianissimo (pp), piano (p), mezzo piano (mp), mezzo forte (mf), forte (f), and fortissimo (ff)
  • change in dynamic levels- crescendo and decrescendo
  • and meters
  • countermelodies

Sing a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • pattern of a dotted quarter note followed by an eighth note or eighth rest
  • variety of tempi (e.g., lento, presto)
  • major and minor tonalities
  • various dynamic levels
  • and meter
  • more complex forms and harmonies (e.g., two-part lines, twelve-bar blues)

Sing a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • pattern of a dotted eighth note followed by a sixteenth note or sixteenth rest
  • variety of tempi (e.g., grave, vivace)
  • major and minor tonalities
  • various dynamic levels
  • , or cut time, meter
  • more complex forms and harmonies (e.g., theme and variations, three-part lines)

Sing a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • syncopation
  • variety of tempi
  • major and minor tonalities
  • various dynamic levels
  • compound and mixed meter
  • more complex forms and harmonies
Play

Play a variety of simple songs alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • fast and slow
  • high and low pitch
  • loud and soft

Play a variety of simple songs alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • quarter notes, quarter rests, and paired eighth notes
  • fast and slow
  • melodic patterns (e.g., sol-mi/5-3, sol-mi-la/5-3-6)
  • dynamic levels- forte (f) and piano (p)
  • duple and triple meter

Play a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • half notes and half rests
  • fast and slow
  • more complex melodic patterns (e.g., sol-mi-lado/5-3-6-1, steps, skips, repeating tones)
  • dynamic levels- forte (f) and piano (p)
  • duple and triple meter
  • call and response

Play a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • dotted half notes
  • variety of tempi (e.g., allegro, adagio)
  • more complex melodic patterns (e.g., pentatonic scale, steps, skips, leaps, repeating tones)
  • change in dynamic levels- crescendo and decrescendo
  • duple and triple meter

Play a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • whole notes and whole rests, four sixteenth notes, and triplets
  • variety of tempi changes (e.g., accelerando, ritardando)
  • more complex melodic patterns
  • variety of dynamic levels [e.g., pianissimo (pp), mezzo piano (mp), mezzo forte (mf), fortissimo (ff)]
  • duple and triple meter

Play a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • eighth note and sixteenth note patterns
  • variety of tempi (e.g., andante, moderato)
  • major tonalities
  • dynamic levels- pianissimo (pp), piano (p), mezzo piano (mp), mezzo forte (mf), forte (f), and fortissimo (ff)
  • change in dynamic levels- crescendo and decrescendo
  • and meters

Play a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • pattern of a dotted quarter note followed by an eighth note or eighth rest
  • variety of tempi (e.g., lento, presto)
  • major and minor tonalities
  • various dynamic levels
  • and meters
  • more complex forms and harmonies (e.g., two-part lines, twelve-bar blues)

Play a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • pattern of a dotted eighth note followed by a sixteenth note or sixteenth rest
  • variety of tempi (e.g., grave, vivace)
  • major and minor tonalities
  • various dynamic levels
  • , or cut time, meter
  • more complex forms and harmonies (e.g., theme and variations, three-part lines)

Play a varied repertoire alone and with others
  • steady beat
  • syncopation
  • variety of tempi
  • major and minor tonalities
  • various dynamic levels
  • compound and mixed meter
  • more complex forms and harmonies
Techniques

Use correct techniques
  • speaking, singing, whispering, and calling voices
  • found sounds
  • body percussion
  • classroom instruments
Identify the role of a conductor

Use correct techniques
  • vocal exploration
  • found sounds
  • body percussion
  • classroom instruments
Recognize cues from a conductor

Demonstrate correct techniques
  • vocal exploration
  • found sounds
  • body percussion
  • classroom instruments
  • posture-vocal and instrumental
Respond to simple conducting patterns

Demonstrate correct techniques
  • vocal exploration
  • found sounds
  • body percussion
  • classroom instruments
  • posture-vocal and instrumental
  • breathing
  • phrasing
Respond to simple conducting patterns

Demonstrate correct techniques
  • vocal exploration
  • found sounds
  • body percussion
  • classroom instruments
  • posture-vocal and instrumental
  • breathing
  • phrasing
  • articulation
  • performance skills
Demonstrate and respond to simple conducting patterns

Refine correct techniques
  • vocal exploration
  • found sounds
  • body percussion
  • classroom instruments
  • posture-vocal and instrumental
  • breathing
  • phrasing
  • articulation
Demonstrate and respond to simple conducting patterns

Refine correct techniques
  • vocal exploration
  • found sounds
  • body percussion
  • classroom instruments
  • posture-vocal and instrumental
  • breathing
  • phrasing
  • articulation
Interpret and respond to a conductor

Refine correct techniques
  • vocal exploration
  • found sounds
  • body percussion
  • classroom instruments
  • posture-vocal and instrumental
  • breathing
  • phrasing
  • articulation
Interpret and respond to a conductor

Refine correct techniques
  • vocal exploration
  • found sounds
  • body percussion
  • classroom instruments
  • posture-vocal and instrumental
  • breathing
  • phrasing
  • articulation
Interpret and respond to artistic conducting
Read

Read using icons
  • steady beat
  • sound and silence
Identify icons for high and low sounds

Read
  • quarter notes, quarter rests, and paired eighth notes
  • simple melodic patterns (e.g., solmi/ 5-3)
  • dynamic levels- forte (f) and piano (p)
Distinguish between a note on a line and a note in a space (e.g., two-line staff)

Read
  • half notes and half rests
  • melodic patterns (e.g., sol-mi-la/5-3- 6, steps, skips, repeating tones)
  • dynamic levels- forte (f) and piano (p)

Recognize
  • lines and spaces
  • staff
  • treble clef

Identify symbols and terms
  • repeat sign
  • treble clef
  • bar line and double bar line
  • fermata

Read
  • dotted half notes
  • variety of tempi (e.g., allegro, adagio)
  • more complex melodic patterns (e.g., sol-mi-la-dore/ 5-3-6-1-2, steps, skips, leaps, repeating tones)
  • change in dynamic levels- crescendo and decrescendo
  • duple and triple meter
Name the lines and spaces of the treble clef

Identify symbols and terms
  • time signature
  • first and second endings

Read
  • whole notes, whole rests, four sixteenth notes, and triplets
  • variety of tempi changes (e.g., accelerando, ritardando)
  • more complex melodic patterns (e.g., sol-mi-la-dore/ 5-3-6-1-2, steps, skips, leaps, repeating tones)
  • variety of dynamic levels [e.g., pianissimo (pp), mezzo piano (mp), mezzo forte (mf), fortissimo (ff)]
  • duple and triple meter
Name the lines and spaces of the bass clef

Identify symbols and terms
  • bass clef
  • da capo (D.C.)
  • dal segno (D.S.)
  • Coda

Read
  • eighth note and sixteenth note patterns
  • variety of tempi (e.g., andante, moderato)
  • more complex melodic patterns (e.g., do-re-mifa- sol-la-ti-do/1-2-3-4-5-6- 7-8, major scale)
  • dynamic levels- pianissimo (pp), piano (p), mezzo piano (mp), mezzo forte (mf), forte (f), and fortissimo (ff)
  • change in dynamic level-crescendo, decrescendo
  • and meters
Identify notes written on the lines and spaces of the treble clef and bass clef

Apply knowledge of symbols and terms in reading music
  • repeat sign
  • treble clef
  • bass clef
  • bar line and double bar line
  • time signatures
  • fermata
  • simple key signatures

Read
  • pattern of a dotted quarter note followed by an eighth note or eighth rest
  • variety of tempi (e.g., lento, presto)
  • melodic patterns that include accidentals
  • various dynamic levels
  • and meters
  • various forms and harmonies (e.g., two-part lines, twelve-bar blues)
Identify notes written on the lines, spaces, and ledger lines of the treble clef and bass clef

Apply knowledge of symbols and terms in reading music
  • accidentals
  • first and second endings
  • da capo (D.C.)
  • dal segno (D.S.)
  • Coda

Read
  • pattern of a dotted eighth note followed by a sixteenth note or sixteenth rest
  • variety of tempi (e.g., grave, vivace)
  • various dynamic levels
  • , or cut time, meter
  • more complex forms and harmonies (e.g., theme and variations, three-part lines)
  • the intervals within the staff (e.g., Major 6, Perfect 5, Perfect 4, Major 3, Major 2, octave)
Identify notes written on the lines and spaces of the grand staff

Apply knowledge of symbols and terms in reading music
  • additional key signatures
  • grand staff

Read
  • syncopation
  • variety of tempi
  • various dynamic levels
  • compound and mixed meter
  • more complex forms and harmonies
  • the intervals within the staff (e.g., Major 6, Perfect 5, Perfect 4, Major 3, Major 2, octave)
Identify notes written on the lines, spaces, and ledger lines of the grand staff

Apply knowledge of symbols and terms in reading music
  • multiple key signatures within a composition
Notate

Notate using icons
  • steady beat
  • sound and silence

Notate
  • quarter notes, quarter rests, and paired eighth notes

Notate
  • half notes and half rests
  • dynamic levels- forte (f) and piano (p)

Notate
  • dotted half notes
  • change in dynamic levels- crescendo and decrescendo
  • bar line and double bar line
  • repeat sign
  • treble clef

Notate
  • whole notes and whole rests, four sixteenth notes, and triplets
  • duple and triple meter
  • time signature
  • bass clef

Notate
  • eighth note and sixteenth note patterns
  • and time signatures

Notate
  • pattern of a dotted quarter note followed by an eighth note or eighth rest
  • and time signatures

Notate
  • pattern of a dotted eighth note followed by a sixteenth note or sixteenth rest
  • , or cut time, time signature

Notate
  • syncopation

Content Standard 2: Creative Expression
Students shall demonstrate creative expression through music.
Improvise
Improvise short melodic and rhythmic patterns
Improvise simple melodic and rhythmic patterns (e.g., pentatonic scale, four beat patterns, chants)
Improvise melodic and rhythmic patterns (e.g., call and response)
Improvise more complex melodic and rhythmic patterns (e.g., ostinati)
Improvise more complex melodic and rhythmic patterns (e.g., question and answer)
Improvise rhythmic variations on familiar melodies
Improvise rhythms, melodies, and/or accompaniments
Improvise using a variety of sound sources (e.g., computer, electronic sounds)
Improvise rhythmic and melodic variations in a given style and meter (e.g., reggae, blues)
Compose
Create sound effects for songs, poems, and/or stories (e.g., found sounds, body percussion, traditional instruments, electronic keyboards, online sound libraries)
Create short rhythmic patterns
Compose short rhythmic patterns
Compose short melodic patterns
Compose melodic and rhythmic patterns using musical expression
Compose a four-measure phrase
Arrange familiar songs using musical expression
Compose a four-measure phrase with accompaniment
Arrange familiar songs with accompaniment
Compose an original melodic line with accompaniment
Arrange unfamiliar songs using musical expression
Compose an original song using various instruments
Arrange unfamiliar songs with accompaniment
Movement
Respond to music through movement (e.g., gross motor movement, freestyle)
Respond to music through movement (e.g., line and circle games, body percussion)
Respond to music through movement (e.g., duple meter, triple meter, musical games)
Respond to music through movement (e.g., create movement to tell a story, play parties)
Respond to music through movement (e.g., folk and square dances, choreograph a song)
Respond to music through movement (e.g., traditional and improvised conducting patterns)
Respond to music through movement (e.g., create movement to outline musical form)
Respond to music through movement (e.g., create choreography to songs for performance)
Respond to music through movement (e.g., create a song along with movement to teach to younger students)

Content Standard 3: Critical Analysis
Students shall listen to, analyze, describe, and evaluate a variety of music.
Listen/Analyze

Investigate sounds
  • environmental sounds
  • voices
  • classroom instruments

Recognize musical form
  • same or different
Demonstrate appropriate etiquette as a performer and an observer

Identify musical sounds
  • vocal and instrumental
  • accompanied and unaccompanied
  • solo and group

Recognize musical form
  • patterns
  • phrase
Demonstrate appropriate etiquette as a performer and an observer

Identify musical timbre
  • individual instruments
  • male and female
  • children's voices

Recognize musical form
  • verse and refrain
  • AB
  • call and response
Demonstrate appropriate etiquette as a performer and an observer

Identify musical timbre
  • electronic sounds
  • individual instruments

Recognize musical form
  • ABA
Demonstrate appropriate etiquette as a performer and an observer

Identify musical instruments by sight and sound
  • string
  • brass
  • woodwind
  • percussion
  • electronic

Recognize musical form
  • rondo
Demonstrate appropriate etiquette as a performer and an observer

Identify musical instruments by sight and sound
  • string
  • brass
  • woodwind
  • percussion
  • electronic

Recognize musical form
  • theme and variations
Demonstrate appropriate etiquette as a performer and an observer

Identify musical timbre
  • brass
  • string
  • percussion
  • woodwind
  • electronic
  • vocal

Recognize musical texture
  • solo
  • small groups
  • large ensemble

Compare and contrast musical forms
  • popular and imitative forms
  • twelve-bar blues
Demonstrate appropriate etiquette as a performer and an observer

Identify musical sounds
  • electronic
  • non-traditional
  • genres (e.g., women's ensemble, men's ensemble)
Analyze various musical forms
Demonstrate appropriate etiquette as a performer and an observer

Distinguish musical sounds
  • western and non-western
  • traditional and nontraditional
  • cross cultural
Analyze various musical forms
Demonstrate appropriate etiquette as a performer and an observer
Evaluate
Identify personal responses to a musical example (e.g., happy, sad)
Illustrate personal responses to a musical example
Discuss a musical example using applicable musical terms [e.g., fast, slow, piano (p), forte (f)]
Describe a musical example using applicable musical elements
Evaluate music using a teacher-generated rubric
Evaluate performances and compositions using a student-generated rubric
Evaluate performances and compositions using a student-generated rubric
Evaluate performances and compositions using a student-generated rubric
Evaluate performances and compositions using a student-generated rubric

Content Standard 4: Connections
Students shall demonstrate and apply knowledge of connections between music and other disciplines.
Historical/Cultural

Respond to music from various cultures, historical periods, and/ or events (e.g., lullabies, nursery rhymes, celebration and holiday songs)
  • listening
  • singing
  • moving
  • playing

Identify connections
  • between music and the other fine arts (e.g., visual art)
  • between music and disciplines outside the arts (e.g., children's literature)

Respond to music from various cultures, historical periods, and/ or events (e.g., marches, nursery rhymes, chants, celebration and holiday songs)
  • listening
  • singing
  • moving
  • playing

Identify connections
  • between music and the other fine arts
  • between music and disciplines outside the arts

Respond to music from various cultures, historical periods, and/ or events (e.g., folk music from around the world)
  • listening
  • singing
  • moving
  • playing

Identify connections
  • between music and the other fine arts
  • between music and disciplines outside the arts

Respond to music from various cultures, historical periods, and/ or events (e.g., folk music from around the world, patriotic songs)
  • listening
  • singing
  • moving
  • playing

Identify connections
  • between music and the other fine arts
  • between music and disciplines outside the arts

Respond to music from various cultures, historical periods, and/ or events (e.g., folk music, spirituals, patriotic songs, Arkansas songs)
  • listening
  • singing
  • moving
  • playing

Identify connections
  • between music and the other fine arts
  • between music and disciplines outside the arts

Respond to music from various cultures, historical periods, and/or events (e.g., world music, folk music, jazz, spirituals)
  • listening
  • singing
  • moving
  • playing

Identify connections
  • between music and the other fine arts (e.g., theatre, ballet)
  • between music and disciplines outside the arts (e.g., social studies)

Respond to music from various cultures, historical periods, and/or events (e.g., popular, Classical)
  • listening
  • singing
  • moving
  • playing

Identify connections
  • between music and the other fine arts
  • between music and disciplines outside the arts
Investigate music from various cultures, historical periods, and/or events (e.g., singing, listening, researching)

Identify connections
  • between music and the other fine arts
  • between music and disciplines outside the arts
Investigate music from various cultures, historical periods, and/or events (e.g., singing, listening, researching)

Identify connections
  • between music and the other fine arts
  • between music and disciplines outside the arts
Research
Research career opportunities in music (e.g., business, education, performance, music therapy, technology)
Research career opportunities in music (e.g., business, education, performance, music therapy, technology)
Research career opportunities in music (e.g., business, education, performance, music therapy, technology)
Research career opportunities in music (e.g., business, education, performance, music therapy, technology)

Standard 5: Foundations
Students shall explore and demonstrate an understanding of the concepts, practices, and historical foundations in the visual arts.
Elements of Art
Investigate lines
Investigate basic shapes (e.g., circle, square, triangle)
Identify basic colors
Investigate actual and tactile texture
Recognize various lines
Recognize basic shapes (e.g., circle, square, triangle)
Investigate form
Identify primary colors
Experiment with colors
Identify actual and tactile textures
Identify spatial relationships (e.g., front, back, over, under, beside)
Categorize line types (e.g., vertical, horizontal, diagonal, zigzag, curved)
Categorize geometric forms, free forms, and organic shapes
Identify a variety of forms (e.g., sphere, cone, cube)
Distinguish between primary and secondary colors on the color wheel and in works of art
Experiment with color mixing
Investigate actual, tactile, and implied (visual) textures (e.g., texture rubbings)
Recognize space and depth (e.g., overlapping, size relationships)
Describe ways line combinations are used to communicate (e.g., line variations as in thick, thin, dashed, broken, rough, smooth)
Describe ways shape combinations are used to communicate (e.g., multiple shapes used in drawing complex objects)
Differentiate between geometric forms, free forms, and organic forms
Identify color concepts [e.g., intermediate (tertiary), color wheel]
Experiment with color mixing
Distinguish between actual, tactile, and implied (visual) textures
Develop concepts of space and depth (e.g., foreground, middle ground, background, horizon line)
Discover line concepts and combinations (e.g., implied, contour, textural, gesture, parallel, perpendicular)
Examine shapes as symbols (e.g., logos, stop signs, universal symbols)
Examine form combinations (e.g., sculptural, architectural)
Develop basic color theory (e.g., value, color schemes, color wheel)
Describe ways color combinations are used to communicate emotion and symbolic use (e.g., red means anger or stop)
Experiment with the creation of implied and actual texture
Investigate basic perspective (e.g., overlapping, size relationships, distance)
Demonstrate knowledge of qualities of line and line variations (e.g., implied line, line as texture and pattern)
Compare and contrast the physical relationships of shapes and forms (e.g., 2-D nets or templates, positive and negative space)
Demonstrate knowledge of the color wheel and color values
Identify other elements of art as components of texture (e.g., use of line in crosshatching)
Investigate artists' use of various perspective techniques
Demonstrate knowledge of value (e.g., gradation)
Develop variations of line types and line qualities
Identify 3-D form in 2-D work using the elements of space (e.g., positive and negative) and value (e.g., shadows and light)
Demonstrate knowledge of color relationships from the color wheel (e.g., warm and cool color schemes)
Demonstrate texturing techniques to enhance artwork
Investigate various perspective techniques (e.g., linear, atmospheric)
Demonstrate knowledge of value to create form (e.g., sphere, cone, cube, cylinder, pyramid)
Use various types of lines in a work of art
Demonstrate knowledge of various categories of 2-D shapes and 3-D forms (e.g., curved and angular, sculpture in-the-round, relief)
Demonstrate knowledge of color schemes in a work of art (e.g., monochromatic, analogous, complementary)
Analyze various textures in the environment and artists' work
Use implied texture to simulate actual texture from the environment
Demonstrate techniques used to create spatial relationships (e.g., atmospheric perspective, linear perspective)
Demonstrate full range of value in a work of art
Demonstrate the application of line characteristics in a work of art
Apply knowledge of 2-D shapes and 3-D forms in artworks (e.g., develop shapes into forms)
Apply knowledge of specific formal color relationships (e.g., color schemes, split complementary, triads, color juxtaposition)
Replicate simulated or implied texture using appropriate media choices
Create a sense of depth in an artwork by combining linear and atmospheric perspectives
Demonstrate application of value from direct observation to show contrast
Principles of Design
Investigate patterns
Identify size relationships (e.g., big to little, tall to short)
Recognize patterns
Investigate proportion and scale in shapes (e.g., large to small)
Identify simple patterns
Investigate the connection between patterns and rhythm (e.g., regular, random)
Recognize scale between objects
Recognize symmetrical balance
Investigate positive and negative space
Experiment with value
Identify student-created patterns
Investigate the connection between pattern and movement (e.g., alternating, progressive)
Compare and contrast scale between objects
Recognize proportion within objects
Recognize symmetrical balance
Investigate the center of interest as emphasis in a work of art
Identify positive and negative space
Investigate value techniques (e.g., cross-hatching, stippling, shading)
Identify complex patterns
Investigate the connection of pattern, rhythm, and movement (e.g., regular, random, alternating, progressive, flowing)
Identify proportions and scale (e.g., portraits)
Compare and contrast proportion within an object (e.g., general, exaggerated)
Recognize radial balance
Investigate harmony and unity in works of art
Investigate variety in a work of art
Examine the center of interest as emphasis in a work of art
Use previous knowledge to explore complex patterns (e.g., random, band, border, row, grid, tessellations)
Recognize visual rhythm in works of art (e.g., alternating, progressive, directional, spatial, Op Art)
Demonstrate knowledge of proportion and scale (e.g., still life, landscape)
Recognize asymmetrical balance
Recognize harmony and unity in works of art
Describe variety in a work of art
Identify use of a focal point as a way to create emphasis in works of art
Demonstrate knowledge of complex patterns which occur in the environment and in works of art (e.g., row, grid, half drop, tessellations)
Demonstrate various types of movement and rhythm in works of art (e.g., actual movement, recorded action)
Demonstrate knowledge of proportion and scale (e.g., exaggerated proportions, caricature, cartooning)
Distinguish among types of balance (e.g., symmetrical, asymmetrical, radial)
Locate harmony and unity in works of art
Identify the elements of art used to create variety in a work of art
Identify a variety of ways to create emphasis in works of art
Demonstrate knowledge of complex patterns which occur in the environment and in works of art (e.g., grid, Fibonacci patterns, fractals, tessellations)
Demonstrate various types of movement and rhythm within works of art (e.g., compositional movement)
Explain the impact of proportion and scale in works of art (e.g., architectural renderings, blueprints)
Categorize different types of balance in works of art and in the environment
Identify the use of the elements of art to unify a work of art
Identify the elements of art used to create variety in a work of art
Examine the use of contrast to create emphasis in works of art
Demonstrate knowledge of complex patterns which occur in the environment and in works of art (e.g., grid, radial, alternating, Fibonacci patterns, fractals, tessellations)
Demonstrate various types of movement and rhythm within works of art (e.g., illusion, flowing, alternating, progressive, unexpected)
Analyze the use of proportion and scale in works of art (e.g., figurative, facial, architecture)
Demonstrate an understanding of different types of balance used to communicate feelings and ideas in works of art
Identify the use of the elements of art to unify a work of art
Evaluate the effective use of elements of art to create variety in a work of art
Recognize ways to achieve emphasis (e.g., placement, contrast, detail, size, grouping)
Historical Foundations
Name various purposes for creating art (e.g., beauty, functional, enjoyment, fun, careers, environmental)
Name various purposes for creating art (e.g., beauty, functional, enjoyment, fun, careers, environmental)
Provide examples of various purposes for creating art (e.g., aesthetic, functional, historical, cultural, therapeutic, social, enjoyment, career, environmental)
Demonstrate an understanding of various purposes for creating art (e.g., aesthetic, functional, historical, cultural, therapeutic, social, enjoyment, careers, environmental)
Demonstrate an understanding of various purposes for creating art (e.g., aesthetic, functional, historical, cultural, therapeutic, social, enjoyment, careers, environmental)
Recognize the importance of art history in relation to the artistic process
Demonstrate an understanding for the various purposes for creating art (e.g., aesthetic, functional, historical, cultural, therapeutic, social, enjoyment, careers, environmental)
Recognize the importance of art history in relation to the artistic process
Demonstrate an understanding for the various purposes for creating art (e.g., aesthetic, functional, historical, cultural, therapeutic, social, enjoyment, careers, environmental)
Relate the importance of art history to the artistic process
